question: Which method is used to align an unreferenced dataset with one that has spatial reference information? (Choose the best response)

question: In a map showing contours, the name of the darker contour lines is (Choose the best response)

question: A small-scale map would show
choice1: A larger geographic area than a large-scale map
choice2: A smaller geographic area than a large-scale map
choice3: The same geographic area as a large-scale map, just at a smaller resolution
choice4: The same geographic area as a large-scale map, just at a larger resolution

question: When mapping sensitive data, what are some techniques that can be used to not reveal details of the data? (Select all that apply)
choice1: Show the data as a heat map
choice2: Show the data as a point layer
choice3: Label the addresses that correspond to the data
choice4: Aggregate the data into quantities using graduated colors, symbols or proportional symbols

question: How does using multiple attributes by category make a map more informative?
choice1: It makes the map more colorful
choice2: It provides the reader with multiple layers of information that are easily recognizable on the map
choice3: It shows a high level of expertise has been obtained by the map creator
choice4: Multiple attributes only clutter up a map

question: Which of the following data formats would most likely represent a file exported from AutoDesk-AutoCAD?

Numerous employees in your organization need access to the streets data that your team is responsible for maintaining in an enterprise database. From the options given below, what is the best way to handle access to these data? (Choose the best response)
choice1: Set the street layer’s permissions to allow everyone in your enterprise full control
choice2: Set the street layer’s permission to allow full control only to your team
choice3: Set the street layer’s permission to allow full control only to your team and read-only access to the remainder of your enterprise
choice4: Set up a download site for everyone in your enterprise. Direct access to these data will be restricted to your team only.

question: A third-party software system is being stored, distributed and maintained by a county agency that provides access based on a fee charged to each local jurisdiction. What would be the safest and most efficient ways to add a new user? (Select all that apply)
choice1: Let anyone sign on as a user as long as they notify the county agency afterward
choice2: Notify the county agency that you would like to add a user and have them do it
choice3: Request that the county agency set up an administrator account for your jurisdiction and allow you to have oversight of your users

question: The local county health department has provided data on EMS calls and ER calls in order for a county GIS department to produce maps showing patterns and density of calls. What restrictions would be involved in using this data? (Choose the best response)
What roles are a database administrator expected to fill? (Select all that apply)
choice1: Create database security settings which reflect the needs of the organization

question: Several characteristics of GIS services that make it difficult to design GIS web services with satisfactory performance. These include (Select all that apply)
choice2: GIS services sometimes transmit large images
choice3: Clients of GIS services are often complex software packages
choice4: GIS is not scalable to web services

question: Leveraging GIS to support an enterprise environment can be best accomplished using which of the following approaches?
choice1: Write-protected shapefiles located on each employee’s workstation
choice2: Geodatabases stored on a centralized server
choice3: Geospatial data served as map services and web maps
choice4: A well-staffed GIS department that is able to response all questions required for the enterprise

question: Which of these types of online information could NOT be referenced in a hyperlink field within a GIS data table?
choice2: Precipitation data for rain gage points
choice4: Construction project information for roadway lines

question: You have been assigned team lead on the development of a new GIS database for a large county. From the options given below, what is the best approach to this project?
choice1: You and your team should study the county and develop the database for them based on your expert knowledge of GIS
choice2: You and your team should interview end-users at the county to learn how this enterprise functions and then design a database to satisfy their particular needs
choice3: You and your team should acquire a copy of the county’s geospatial data and convert it into the Local Government Information Model (LGIM). Delivery of this end-product will setup the county for their long-term needs
choice4: Both a and c are equally correct.

question: Object-relational databases have become the cornerstone of modern GIS. These databases can be best described in which of the following ways:
choice1: Each database contains one table and one GIS layer
choice2: The database contains one attribute table for each GIS layer. The attribute table may contain numerous fields (attributes)
choice3: The database will contain many GIS layers, each with an attribute table. The attribute table may contain numerous fields (attributes)
choice4: The database will contain many GIS layers, each with an associated attribute table. In addition, other tables may exist that further describe specific characteristics of the GIS layer and are associated with the GIS layer through a relationship. Each table may contain numerous fields (attributes).

question: One common task faced by the GIS professional is the assurance of data quality and correctness. An example of this is ensuring all County polygons fall within the polygon of their respective State. This can be accomplished using which of the following workflows?
choice1: Clip the Counties polygon layer with the State polygon layer. Then check if the counties layer changed. If so, it is understood that the Counties layer was larger than the State layer, thus requiring further action.
choice2: Apply a topology rule to the Geodatabase feature dataset containing County and State polygon feature classes and determine if the State feature class is covered by the Counties feature class
choice3: Apply a topology rule to the folder containing County and State shapefiles and determine if the State feature class is covered by the Counties feature class
choice4: Simply sum the area of the Counties layer and State layer. If they agree it is safe to assume they share consistent topology

What are good reasons to use scale-dependant rendering that changes the source of a dataset to a less detailed and less accurate dataset as the scale of the map is made smaller? (Select all that apply)

choice2: To make features appear larger than they are
choice3: To reduce cluttered/confusing representations in map products
choice4: To encourage the viewer to overlook important details

question: Representing features logically in GIS format requires knowledge of GIS primitives. The scale at which a feature is intended to be shown can help define the proper primitive used to create and display that feature. The best option to represent a feature class for rivers in a State-wide map would be: (Choose the best response)

You have been asked to analyze ground water quality for a largely rural American county. During your analysis you learn that septic tank density has a correlation coefficient of 0.15 with ground water nitrate concentrations. From these data, you can safely infer
choice1: Septic tanks appear to contribute to the Counties ground water nitrate concerns. However, additional factors are also involved and need to be investigated.
choice2: Septic tanks have increased nitrate concentration by 15%. Therefore, restricting future septic tank installations is important for the counties ground water quality.
choice3: Septic tanks have increased nitrate concentration by 15%. Therefore, restricting future septic tank installations is important for the counties ground water quality. In addition, the County needs to seriously consider extending existing sewer lines to thereby reduce the number of septic tanks.
choice4: The correlation coefficient of 0.15 is very low and fails to show any correlation between septic tanks and the Counties ground water concerns regarding nitrates.

While it can consist of several files with different file name extensions, three file names are needed to be properly identified as a shapefile. These are: (Choose the best response)
Calculations (sum, average, median, etc.) can’t be performed on this type of field (Choose the best response)
When converting Degrees/Minutes/Seconds of latitude in the Northern Hemisphere to decimal degrees (Choose the best response)
choice1: Add the three values together and divide the sum by 3600, i.e., (Deg+Min+Sec)/3600
choice2: Subtract the seconds from the minutes, then the minutes from the degrees i.e. (Deg-(Min-Sec))
choice3: Multiply the Minutes by 60, multiply the seconds by 3600 and then add all to the degrees, i.e., (Deg+(Min60)+(Sec3600))
choice4: Divide the Seconds by 3600, divide the Minutes by 60, then add those values to the degrees, i.e. (Deg+(Min/60)+(Sec/3600))

question: If converting Degrees/Minutes/Seconds of latitude in the Southern Hemisphere to decimal degrees, what would change from question 39? (Choose the best response)
choice1: You would add the derived value to 180
choice2: You would subtract the derived value from 180
choice3: You would multiply the derived value by -1
choice4: You would divide the derived value by -1

question: How would you determine the horizontal accuracy of an ortho-rectified aerial image? (Choose the best response)
choice1: The image is compared to a historic photograph and 90% of the well-known points must match
choice2: Photo-identifiable field points are surveyed and the Root-Mean Square error between the image and the Photo-ID points is computed
choice3: Points are heads-up digitized from the ortho-rectified aerial image and compared to points from GIS layers
choice4: The image is compared to a historic photograph and 90% of the well-known points must match

question: What is the most common statistical method to determine the attribute (land classification) accuracy of a raster- derived land use/land cover map? (Choose the best response)
choice1: Use photo-identifiable points for ground truthing and compute a RMSe
choice2: Have multiple technicians compile vector polygons and then do a Union Overlay. The total area of the sliver polygons is the statistical error
choice3: Compute a Confusion Matrix based on ground truthing a stratified random sample of polygons
choice4: Compute the variance in the number of polygons of each land use/land cover class

question: The Federal Geographic Data Committee has endorsed
choice1: only the Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata (CSDGM)
choice2: only the ISO 19115 Geospatial Metadata Standard
choice3: only the CSDGM and the ISO 19115 standards
choice4: Have multiple technicians measure football fields end zone to end zone (300 feet) (or other well-known structures) and the standard deviation of those measurements is the accuracy.

choice2: Ease of access to historical data

question: Which of the following is used to extract features and their attributes from one layer using a polygon from another as the boundary of the output?

Which of the following appends together layers of adjoining area? (Choose the best response)
What are some important considerations when converting hand-drawn features from a hard copy map to digital GIS data? (Select all that apply)
choice1: Colors that will be used to show data in final maps
choice2: Determining which background data shown on the paper maps is the most accurate to use in georeferencing it
choice3: Method the field data collector used to orient themselves
choice4: Ability to understand the notations made and to interpret the attributes for each feature

question: When collecting GPS data, what are the most important factors in determining the accuracy of the resulting data? (Select all that apply)
choice1: Using templates or prescribed schemas for feature creation to ensure data quality
choice2: The number of and distance between features collected each day
choice3: The capabilities of the GPS receiver and alignment of GPS satellites at the moment the data is collected
choice4: The battery power of the data collection device
